dataModel.name: conservationStatus
constraints: Critically Endangered
Endangered
Vulnerable

dataModel.name: recoveryPlanOrConservationAdvice
constraints: Recovery Plan
Conservation Advice

dataModel.name: overallObjectives
dataModel.description: What were the overall achievements/challenges for the reporting period. Provide a snapshot of the current state/condition of the species/ecological community and the reasons for the identified trends i.e. increased effort in threat abatement in a particular area, emergence of new threats (disease etc.) Comment on any progress towards achieving the objectives of the plan.

columns.name: objective
columns.description: One or two overarching statement(s) relating to recovery of the species or ecological community over the long term. For example: * to reduce the impact of threatening processes and prevent further decline of the species * to improve the population status, leading to future removal of the [species name] from the threatened species list of the EPBC Act; and * to ensure that threatening processes do not impact on the ongoing viability of the [species name].The overall objective should remain unchanged after filling in at the start of the reporting cycle, and guide the sub-objectives and recovery criteria.

columns.name: status
constraints: Objective not achieved
Objective partially achieved
Objective achieved

dataModel.name: condition
dataModel.description: Refer to Conservation assessment criteria found at XXXX to grade the state/ condition of the species/ecological community in terms of the prospects for long term survival in the wild; the conservation trajectory of the entity in terms of whether it is improving, deteriorating, or stable; and your confidence in these estimates based on available data and the consensus of experts. This assessment should be undertaken following completion of the report.
constraints: Very poor
Poor
Good
Very good

dataModel.name: conditionConfidence
constraints: Evidence and consensus too low to make an assessment
Limited evidence or limited consensus
Adequate high-quality evidence and high consensus

dataModel.name: trajectory
constraints: Improving
Deteriorating
Stable
Unclear
dataModel.description: Refer to Conservation assessment criteria found at XXXX to grade the state/ condition of the species/ecological community in terms of the prospects for long term survival in the wild; the conservation trajectory of the entity in terms of whether it is improving, deteriorating, or stable; and your confidence in these estimates based on available data and the consensus of experts. This assessment should be undertaken following completion of the report.

dataModel.name: trajectoryConfidence
constraints: Evidence and consensus too low to make an assessment
Limited evidence or limited consensus
Adequate high-quality evidence and high consensus

dataModel.name: keyHighlights
dataModel.description: What were the overall achievements/challenges for the reporting period. Provide a snapshot of the current state/condition of the species/ecological community and the reasons for the identified trends i.e. increased effort in threat abatement in a particular area, emergence of new threats (disease etc.) Comment on any progress towards achieving the objectives of the plan.

dataModel.name: implementingActions
dataModel.description: What were the overall achievements/challenges for the reporting period. Provide a snapshot of the current state/condition of the species/ecological community and the reasons for the identified trends i.e. increased effort in threat abatement in a particular area, emergence of new threats (disease etc.) Comment on any progress towards achieving the objectives of the plan.

columns.description: The EPBC Act specifies that a recovery plan must identify organisations or persons who will be involved in evaluating the performance of the recovery plan
columns.name: deliveryPartners
constraints: Organisation 1
Organisation 2

columns.name: status
constraints: No / little progress
Some progress
Action completed

dataModel.name: actionsSummary
dataModel.description: In a paragraph or dot points, summarise implementation of the actions (e.g. what worked or didn’t work, any impediments or catalysts, and any other issues encountered).

columns.name: recoveryCriteria
columns.description: The EPBC Act specifies that a recovery plan must state criteria against which achievement of the objectives is to be measured (e.g. a specified number and distribution of viable populations of a species or community, or the abatement of specific threats to a species or community). A recovery plan must identify the criteria against which achievement towards each objective can be assessed. Performance criteria enable measurement of progress towards meeting the objectives and should enable assessment of success or failure. Criteria must be clear and measurable, and each objective may have more than one criterion, but must have at least one.

columns.name: status
constraints: Objective not achieved
Objective partially achieved
Objective achieved

dataModel.name: objectivesSummary
dataModel.description: In a paragraph or dot points, summarise the extent to which actions are contributing to the overall objective or progressing towards it. Include whether and to what extent the sub/objectives are being achieved and the contribution of actions to any achievements. Also state any reasons for the objectives not being achieved and/or the level of success not being measured

columns.name: category
constraints: Abundance
Distribution
Habitat condition
Threats

columns.name: initialCondition
constraints: Very poor
Poor
Good
Very good
columns.description: This applies only to the time the recovery plan was published, and only needs to be completed once in the first progress report. Include reference to measures that are relevant to assessing the species’ or ecological communities’ condition and trajectory (e.g. abundance, distribution, habitat condition, threats). Refer to the recovery plan and/or listing assessment. Please note where data are stored or published

columns.name: currentCondition
constraints: Very poor
Poor
Good
Very good
columns.description: Reference any changes from initial condition, new information etc. Include only information that will be significant in informing the assessment of the current state/condition of the species or ecological community. Include notes on where data are stored or published.

dataModel.name: relevantMonitoringData
dataModel.description: Identify any monitoring programs in place and any assessment of condition/trajectory over the reporting period. Please note where the information is stored and whether it is publicly accessible

dataModel.name: currentStateAndTrajectoryOverview
dataModel.description: Short statement of any changes/trends, etc. For example, the population has remained stable or population x has shown an increase in the number of mature individuals etc. This information should form the basis for completing the ‘summary assessment of progress’ (part 4).

dataModel.name: currentStateSummary
dataModel.description: Summary paragraph/dot points –provide an overall summary of the above evaluation and reasons for your conservation assessment. Consider, for example, if there were any advances in knowledge/ data, any knowledge/data gaps, or a change in the impact of threats. Were any data available from a monitoring program that informed the assessment? How effective has the implementation of the recovery plan been in influencing recovery?

dataModel.name: recoveryTeamSupport
dataModel.description: Provide a brief overview of the operation of the recovery team over the past year, for example: (1) how many times you met, (2) whether there were any community based activities initiated by the team that raised the profile of the species or ecological community, or (3) whether there were any achievements/challenges for the reporting period. Provide a brief assessment of how the recovery team has been influential in driving the effective implementation of the recovery plan. Identify if there have been any unexpected developments which may influence the future course of action or which require urgent review of the recovery plan.

dataModel.name: futureCourseOfAction
dataModel.description: Does the report: (1) necessitate a review of the recovery plan or changes to future planned activities, or (2) propose changes to actions or objectives?Are there any potential opportunities for the coming year e.g. funding opportunities?

dataModel.name: informationSources
dataModel.description: Provide any other information (or web links) that: (1) support the conservation assessment, e.g. publications, reports, monitoring program and/or data; and/or (2) promote the work of the recovery team and successes to date e.g. photos, websites, media stories.

items.source:
Purpose

Monitoring, evaluation and reporting is an important part of any recovery effort. Regular monitoring and assessment of the progress of a recovery program provides clarity on whether investments are improving the status of threatened species and ecological communities. It also enables adaptive management, so that we can adjust our efforts accordingly. Recovery teams have an important leadership role in communicating the effectiveness of recovery programs.

A national reporting framework has been established for recovery teams to report on their progress in achieving the objectives of a recovery plan. Consistent reporting across nationally registered recovery teams will progressively build a national snapshot of species conservation efforts over time. Annual progress reporting will allow teams to build a story on how the species is tracking which will feed into the more comprehensive five-year review of recovery plans and conservation advices. Information from this reporting will also inform other national reporting such as the State of the Environment and in reporting progress against Australia’s international obligations such as the Convention on Biological Diversity. Recovery team reports are to be published on the Department’s website. Please note that the terms recovery plan and conservation advice are considered interchangeable terms in this document.

Guidance

This on -line report is designed to be populated by a recovery team or equivalent governance group overseeing the implementation of a recovery plan. The report is comprised of three main sections describing progress in:

  1. Implementing actions;
  2. meeting objectives; and
  3. tracking changes in condition and conservation trajectory, andthen to finalise the report a summary (snapshot) of the overall health of the threatened species or ecological community is completed to align with the State of the Environment reporting framework.

The report is structured so that each section builds towards an assessment of the current state of the species/ecological community (termed ‘condition’ in this report) and its conservation trajectory. The report provides the opportunity to briefly identify key recovery team activities and proposed activities in the coming year/s. Reporting should also highlight any issues or difficulties encountered in the plan’s implementation.

It is important to report all results, whether positive or negative and to what extent actions have been implemented and what (if any) impediments there have been to implementing the actions or meeting the objectives of the recovery plan. This can guide future recovery priorities and facilitate the identification of opportunities for reassessing the approaches taken and future investment in action. As part of the adaptive management cycle, regular ongoing reviews will help indicate whether the recovery actions remain appropriate for achieving the objectives or whether a different approach is needed.

It is intended that the first report be the foundation for subsequent reports. Much of the information can be added in the first year, while subsequent years will provide the opportunity to update the report, adding information and actions progressed in that reporting period. It is intended that the progress report will be completed annually for the first four years of the life of the recovery plan and then in the fifth year the statutory five year recovery plan review will be completed.

It is acknowledged that some recovery plans cover multiple species and that the objectives/actions target multiple species. These should be collectively reported on as identified in the recovery plan, but it is desirable that the assessment of conservation trajectory be undertaken for each individual species or ecological community.

Reporting should be completed on or close to the anniversary date of when the recovery plan was first published.

items.preLabel: Conservation status under EPBC Act Advice
Please attach a representative image of the species or ecological community

items.source: List the actions as identified in the recovery plan. Against each action describe briefly the extent to which it was implemented including activities undertaken and any achievements or outcomes. Identify any issues or impediments to implementation. Where known, include the investment in actions to date and identify the contributors to implementing actions. Identify any additional actions that were undertaken that are not in the current recovery plan and provide a rationale for their inclusion. Assign the appropriate status term for each action.

List the sub-objectives and recovery criteria    as identified in the recovery plan. Use the recovery criteria or other measures to assess the extent to which the objectives were achieved, the contribution of actions to any achievements, and any known reasons for objectives not being achieved and/or the level of success not being measured (including, if relevant, the appropriateness of the original sub-objectives and criteria). Assign the appropriate status term for each sub-objective
3. Tracking changes in the state / condition and conservation trajectory

This field considers what has been learned over the life of the report. It considers the condition and trajectory of the species when the recovery plan was first approved, the present condition and trajectory, and the extent to which the plan influenced any change in the condition or trajectory.
Please delete the rows that are not applicable

items.preLabel: What is the current state/condition and conservation trajectory?

items.source:
The format for reporting on ‘current condition’ and ‘current trajectory’ of threatened species and ecological communities follows the assessment summaries presented in the Australia State of the Environment 2011 and 2016 reports. Like those reports, this ‘Summary assessment of progress’ comprises a short synopsis and graphical representation of the key results of the assessments, providing an at-a-glance view of the current conservation status.

The measures used to assess condition and trajectory should be those relating to the EPBC Act listing criteria for species and ecological communities, facilitating any future reassessment. Importantly, the measures used must be consistent over the reporting period. The Guidelines for using the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria should also be consulted when considering appropriate measures for particular taxa and the available evidence.
Provide any additional information relating to the operation of the recovery team and any future course of action of the recovery team as well as any supporting information for the reporting period.
